articles.headline: Bank of America Settles S.E.C. Suit Over Merrill Deal
articles.snippet: The S.E.C. accused Bank of America of misleading investors about plans to pay billions of dollars in bonuses at Merrill Lynch, the troubled brokerage giant it bought last year.
articles.abstract: The S.E.C. accused Bank of America of misleading investors about plans to pay billions of dollars in bonuses at Merrill Lynch, the troubled brokerage giant it bought last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a watershed moment of the financial crisis  a you-must-be-kidding payday that prompted a state investigation and an outcry in Congress. And, for Kenneth D. Lewis, it has become a nagging, multibillion-dollar headache.

articles.headline: Income Loss Persists Long After Layoffs
articles.snippet: It can take years for income to bounce back after a layoff, and even longer in a recession, if at all, economists say.
articles.abstract: It can take years for income to bounce back after a layoff, and even longer in a recession, if at all, economists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVIERA BEACH, Fla.  Chuck Dettman said he had not really considered the notion back in 2001 that he and his friends in a job-search support group would never recover from being laid off.

articles.headline: Spurring Sales, Car Rebate Plan Is Left Up in Air
articles.snippet: Approval of more funding for the “cash for clunkers” program took a step forward as it won the support of two senators who had earlier criticized the plan.
articles.abstract: Approval of more funding for the “cash for clunkers” program took a step forward as it won the support of two senators who had earlier criticized the plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The fate of the “cash for clunkers” program remained uncertain on Monday even as sales figures from automakers demonstrated that people had flocked to dealers to trade in old gas guzzlers.
articles.byline: By Matthew L. Wald and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: New Leader Tries to Get Toyota Back on the Road
articles.snippet: Known for reliability, Toyota has a lineup of mundane-looking vehicles that have failed to generate excitement among buyers.
articles.abstract: Known for reliability, Toyota has a lineup of mundane-looking vehicles that have failed to generate excitement among buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors, Ford and Chrysler are not the only ones working through wrenching restructurings. Toyota is, as well, though with a much lower profile.

articles.headline: Fears of Fraud Cast Pall Over Afghan Election
articles.snippet: With insurgents active in half the country, many Afghans remain doubtful that the election will take place.
articles.abstract: With insurgents active in half the country, many Afghans remain doubtful that the election will take place.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Little more than three weeks before the presidential election, problems that include insecurity and fears of fraud are raising concerns about the credibility of the race, which President Obama has called the most important event in Afghanistan this year.

articles.headline: Keeping Their Eggs in Their Backyard Nests
articles.snippet: As a backyard poultry trend sweeps the country, hatcheries that supply baby chicks say they can barely keep up with demand.
articles.abstract: As a backyard poultry trend sweeps the country, hatcheries that supply baby chicks say they can barely keep up with demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Americans struggle through a dismal recession, many are trying to safeguard themselves from what they fear will be even worse times ahead. They eat out less often. They take vacations closer to home. They put off buying new cars.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Taps Former Chief of MetLife
articles.snippet: The American International Group said it has appointed Robert H. Benmosche as its new chief executive, its second since receiving billions of dollars in federal aid.
articles.abstract: The American International Group said it has appointed Robert H. Benmosche as its new chief executive, its second since receiving billions of dollars in federal aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group has found another executive willing to come out of retirement to take on the thankless task of leading a troubled insurer that was brought to the brink of financial collapse before being rescued through multibillion-dollar bailouts from the government.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Bill Clinton in North Korea to Seek Release of U.S. Reporters
articles.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton went to North Korea to negotiate the release of two American television journalists who were sentenced to 12 years of hard labor.
articles.abstract: Former President Bill Clinton went to North Korea to negotiate the release of two American television journalists who were sentenced to 12 years of hard labor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton went to North Korea on Monday to negotiate the release of two American television journalists who were sentenced to 12 years of hard labor for illegally entering North Korean territory, a person who was briefed on the mission said.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Peter Baker

articles.headline: In Release of Journalists, Both Clintons Had Key Roles
articles.snippet: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had proposed sending various people to lobby for the release of two journalists before Bill Clinton emerged as the preferred choice, people briefed on the talks said.
articles.abstract: Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton had proposed sending various people to lobby for the release of two journalists before Bill Clinton emerged as the preferred choice, people briefed on the talks said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Former President Bill Clinton left North Korea on Wednesday morning after a dramatic 20-hour visit, in which he won the freedom of two American journalists, opened a diplomatic channel to North Korea’s reclusive government and dined with the North’s ailing leader, Kim Jong-il.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Peter Baker
